text: so privacy and data security is top of
the mind at the moment and gdpr was
perhaps at one point maybe considered a
bit of a burden by most organizations
but how do you think that the changing
perception and public concern around
privacy and security is impacting that
do you think that perhaps gdpr is even
presenting a bit of an opportunity
indeed so I think juniper is presenting
a bit of an opportunity because the way
organizations actually collect sent and
manage and dispose of data these days we
live in a in a time when we've got
unprecedented access point to
information we collect a lot of data and
that's quite often includes personal
data but it also includes various other
telemetric information that there's
organizations and individuals generates
we also aggregate the data and we in a
position to analyze it as well and
perhaps derive intelligence on the back
of that and that raises the question of
what are we actually living in society
which which handles data and their
access to data in a fair fashion is it
the case that some organizations give
access to more data and therefore
they're privileged and perhaps in a
better position to to leverage that data
for economic and and perhaps political
reasons as well and yes I appreciate
that many individuals and organizations
are concerned about the facts that data
is probably not accessible to everyone
and at the same time certain
organizations may be abusing abusing
data as well I agree and perhaps we
always need to find the right balance
between getting data available to two
organizations for the purposes of
analyzing it and deriving intelligence
and ultimately achieving good outcomes
on the back of using such information
and at the same time abusing data is
certainly something that we need to
avoid that's the reason why GDP is there
to regulate and establish the
foundations upon which organizations at
least when it comes to personal data
should be able to to collect aggregates
analyze and and manage information in
the long run Tim a burden or an
opportunity I think it's it represents
an opportunity for a lot of different
organizations even organizations that
have a well-established and
well-developed
cybersecurity program
the reason I think that is most
compliance regulations are sort of
checkbox exercises where you're trying
to go through a range of controls and
ensure that they're turned on turned off
whatever the case may be
gdpr is different instead of requiring
compliance and kind of embracing
compliance as a security strategy this
is really you need to have a strategy in
order to comply to gdpr so it's a little
different and I think that's where the
opportunity is because now the
organizations that have been struggling
with cybersecurity programs if they
embrace gdpr they can actually get
markedly better cybersecurity out of
that investment in complying with gdpr
